title: 108_hr2723
content:
The Act is titled the "Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals Judgeship and Reorganization Act of 2003." It defines terms like "former ninth circuit," "new ninth circuit," and "twelfth circuit." The Act also addresses the number and composition of circuits. SEC. 3 amends Section 41 of title 28, United States Code, increasing the number of circuits to fourteen and redefining the ninth and twelfth circuits. The President will appoint additional circuit judges for the former ninth circuit court of appeals in Arizona, California, or Nevada, as well as for the new ninth circuit court of appeals. These appointments will not be made before January 21, 2005. The President will appoint additional circuit judges for the former ninth circuit court of appeals in Arizona, California, or Nevada. The first 2 vacancies on the new ninth circuit court of appeals occurring 10 years after judges are confirmed to fill temporary circuit judgeships created by this subsection shall not be filled. This section will take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act. The table in title 28, United States Code, is amended to increase the number of circuit judges for the ninth and twelfth circuits. The places of the circuit court are also updated to include San Francisco, Pasadena, and Phoenix for the ninth circuit. The former ninth circuit judges will be assigned to the new ninth circuit or twelfth circuit based on their duty station before the effective date of the Act. Senior judges can elect their assignment. Senior judges from the former ninth circuit can choose to be assigned to the new ninth circuit or twelfth circuit. Their seniority will be based on their commission date as a judge of the former ninth circuit. On the day before the effective date of this Act, appeals or proceedings filed with the former ninth circuit will be handled accordingly. If the matter has been submitted for decision, proceedings will continue as if the Act had not been enacted. If not submitted, the case will be transferred to the appropriate court for further proceedings. The petition for rehearing or rehearing en banc in a matter decided before the effective date of this Act will be treated as if the Act had not been enacted. If rehearing en banc is granted, the matter will be reheard by a court as if the Act had not been enacted. SEC. 11 allows for temporary assignment of circuit judges between the Ninth and Twelfth Circuits, upon request by the chief judges. SEC. 12 allows for temporary assignment of district judges between circuits. Section 292 of title 28, United States Code, allows for temporary assignment of district judges between the Ninth and Twelfth Circuits in the public interest. The chief judge of each circuit can designate and assign judges to sit on the Court of Appeals or hold district court in the other circuit when necessary. The Twelfth Circuit can sit on the Court of Appeals of the Ninth Circuit when needed. District judges can also be temporarily assigned to hold district court in any district within the Ninth Circuit. Designations and assignments must comply with the rules of the court of appeals of the designated circuit. SEC. 13. ADMINISTRATIVE COORDINATION.

Section 332 of title 28, United States Code, amended to allow 2 contiguous circuits to jointly carry out administrative functions as determined by their judicial councils.

SEC. 14. ADMINISTRATION.

The court of appeals for the ninth circuit can take necessary administrative action to implement this Act and its amendments, ceasing to exist for administrative purposes on October 1, 2006.

SEC. 15. EFFECTIVE DATE.

This Act and its amendments will take effect on October 1, 2004, except as provided in section 4(c).
